Executive Summary:

A.Introduction:

The Terminal in Meredosia receives fertilizers from barges, stores the fertilizer in tanks, and loads trucks. The facility has one anhydrous ammonia tank and four urea ammonium nitrate (UAN) liquid fertilizer storage tanks.



B.Accidental Release Record: 



The Meredosia Terminal has an excellent safety record with no deaths or serious injuries to facility personnel since it was constructed in 1964. 



The facility safety record is direct result of continued emphasis on safety by management, employees, contractors, and truck drivers. There have not been any releases from the Terminal that require reporting under the RMP five year accident history.



In case of a reportable chemical accident, information in the RMP will be updated within six (6) months of the date accident accrued.



C.General Accidental Release Prevention Policies And Activities:



The entire Nitrogen team works together to ensure the facility complies with OSHA Process Safety Management standards and the accident prevention program are continuously improved. A networked computer management system is utilized to provide our employees with the necessary tools and records to maintain the safety of the process. This teamwork is an integral part in the safety efforts of the facility.



Accident release prevention steps include the fourteen-element program for Process Safety Management, a management system, corporate oversight of the facility, and a focus on continuous improvement.  



The facility encourages all employees to participate in the facility safety program. Examples of employee participation include participation in Process Hazard Analysis, cooperative training, updating of operating procedures, and emergency response activities. 



The facility has well established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pump compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition

. This program includes: 

1.training

2.written operating procedures

3.inspection and test in accordance with recognized standard,

4.correction of deficiencies, 

5.quality assurance



In combination, these activities from a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.



Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plans, and (4) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their job in a safe manner. Written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner, conforms to generally accepted standards, and provides a basis for training. Inspections and test are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits.



The facility has a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology, procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. 



F.Five Year Accident History: 



The Meredosia Terminal has an excellent safety record with no deaths or serious injuries to any of its personnel. In addition, the terminal has operated without a lost time accident for over twenty-eight years. There have not been any incidents that require reporting under the RMP five year accident history.



G.Emergency Response: 



The facility Emergency Action Plans covers accidental releases of plant chemicals, natural disasters, emergency response practices and procedures, and process safety topics. The plan is reviewed at least annually with all employees. 

Each employee and permanent contractor is trained on the facility's Emergency Response policies and procedures at regularly scheduled safety meetings. 



The Emergency Response Plan is followed in the event of an emergency. The emergency alarm system is tested once each wee

k and an emergency response simulation is attended by at least the terminal supervisor annually.



Updates to emergency contact information will be reported within one month of change.



H.Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



The Meredosia Terminal will utilize employee input and industry best management practices to continuously improve safety, environmental, and all operations.



Installation of secondary containment was completed in 2013 and it will hold 110% of the tanks contents.

Flare upgrade project due to be completed in 2014.



I.Summary: 



The Meredosia Terminal and its employees are extremely proud of its safety record and the vast improvements in both safety and environmental. We believe that with the programs and policies in place in our terminal and the continued efforts of 100% of our personnel, we will be able to maintain our safety record and a safe plant environment for all concerned in the years ahead.
